oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An Incident of General Sherman's March Through Georgia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving of Union soldiers being greeted at a plantation home. An African Amreican family can be seen on the right, a group of women and children stand at the top of the stairs of the house.

The "Illustrated London News" was a magazine founded by Herbet Ingram and Mark Lemon. The magazine typically had sixteen pages and thirty-two wood engravings of various popular, contemporary topics. Sherman's march to the sea was a slash and burn action conducted in late 1864. The path of destruction went from Atlanta, Georgia, to Savannah.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Georgia - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891
